user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of need_100_continue:
```c
static bool
need_100_continue (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  const char *expect;

  if (! MHD_IS_HTTP_VER_1_1_COMPAT (connection->rq.http_ver))
    return false;

  if (0 == connection->rq.remaining_upload_size)
    return false;

  if (MHD_NO ==
      MHD_lookup_connection_value_n (connection,
                                     MHD_HEADER_KIND,
                                     MHD_HTTP_HEADER_EXPECT,
                                     MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ ( \
                                       MHD_HTTP_HEADER_EXPECT),
                                     &expect,
                                     NULL))
    return false;

  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_ (expect,
                               "100-continue"))
    return true;

  return false;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function need_100_continue:
bool on
...
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_lookup_connection_value_n (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                               enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                               const char *key,
                               size_t key_size,
                               const char **value_ptr,
                               size_t *value_size_ptr)
{
  struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header *pos;

  if (NULL == connection)
    return MHD_NO;

  if (NULL == key)
  {
    for (pos = connection->rq.headers_received; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)
    {
      if ( (0 != (kind & pos->kind)) &&
           (NULL == pos->header) )
        break;
    }
  }
  else
  {
    for (pos = connection->rq.headers_received; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)
    {
      if ( (0 != (kind & pos->kind)) &&
           (key_size == pos->header_size) &&
           ( (key == pos->header) ||
             (MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (key,
                                             pos->header,
                                             key_size) ) ) )
        break;
    }
  }

  if (NULL == pos)
    return MHD_NO;

  if (NULL != value_ptr)
    *value_ptr = pos->value;

  if (NULL != value_size_ptr)
    *value_size_ptr = pos->value_size;

  return MHD_YES;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (! MHD_IS_HTTP_VER_1_1_COMPAT (connection->rq.http_ver))
    return false;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation evident in the fragment as given. The conditional return is reachable at runtime unless the macro or the http_ver expression is a compile-time constant. A specific violating scenario would be if MHD_IS_HTTP_VER_1_1_COMPAT is defined as a compile-time constant (for example #define MHD_IS_HTTP_VER_1_1_COMPAT(x) (1) or (0)), or if connection->rq.http_ver is known at compile time so the condition always has the same truth value: e.g. if the macro always yields true then the 'return false;' can never be executed (unreachable); if it always yields false then the following code is unreachable because the function always returns there. To determine a real violation, inspect the definition of MHD_IS_HTTP_VER_1_1_COMPAT and whether http_ver is a compile-time constant.
